papers.title: Detection of four cold Jupiters through combined analyses of radial velocity and astrometry data
papers.abstract: Cold Jupiters play a crucial role in planet formation and dynamical evolution. Since their initial discovery around 47 UMa, they have attracted significant interest, yet their formation mechanisms remain uncertain, underscoring the need to expand the known population. In this work, we combine RV data with Gaia astrometry using Hipparcos-Gaia proper-motion anomalies over a 25-year baseline. By jointly modeling both datasets with the MCMC framework, we constrain planetary masses, orbital inclinations, and three-dimensional orbital architectures. This reduces RV degeneracies and improves mass determinations. Four cold Jupiters are reported: HD 68475 b and HD 100508 b are each the first confirmed planet in their systems, with orbital periods $7832_{-323}^{+463}$ d and $5681\pm42$ d and dynamical masses of $5.16_{-0.47}^{+0.53} M_{\text{Jup}}$ and $1.2_{-0.18}^{+0.30} M_{\text{Jup}}$, respectively. In multi-planet systems, HD 48265 c has a period of $10418_{-1400}^{+2400}$ d and a mass of $3.71_{-0.43}^{+0.68} M_{\text{Jup}}$, while HD 114386 c orbits at $444.00_{-0.88}^{+0.93}$ d with a minimum mass of $0.37 \pm 0.03 M_{\text{Jup}}$. The two planets in the HD 48265 system may exhibit a significant mutual inclination, making it a target for testing the von-Zeipel-Kozai-Lidov mechanism. HD 68475 b is a promising candidate for future direct imaging with ELT/METIS. We identified a Jupiter analog with the longest known orbital period among planets with masses between 0.5 and 2 $M_{\text{Jup}}$, implying that a substantial population of cold Jupiters likely awaits discovery by Gaia. This study expands the sample of cold Jupiters with constrained orbits and dynamical masses, demonstrating the value of combining radial velocity and astrometry in exoplanet research.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to understand how planetary systems form by only studying our own solar system—it would be like trying to understand human diversity by studying just one family. Cold Jupiters, massive planets that orbit far from their host stars (similar to how Jupiter orbits far from our Sun), hold crucial clues about how planetary systems develop and evolve. These distant giants may act as cosmic shepherds, influencing where smaller, potentially habitable planets can form and survive. By finding more of these cold Jupiters, astronomers are building a more complete picture of planetary system architecture, which ultimately helps us understand whether systems like our own—with rocky planets in the "Goldilocks zone" where liquid water can exist—are common or rare in the universe.

**What They Did**

The researchers used a detective approach, combining two different methods to hunt for planets orbiting distant stars. First, they used the "wobble method"—when a planet orbits a star, it causes the star to wobble slightly due to gravitational pull, like a hammer thrower spinning in circles. Second, they tracked tiny changes in stellar positions using space telescopes over 25 years, looking for stars that seemed to "drift" from their expected paths due to unseen planetary companions. By combining these techniques using sophisticated computer modeling, they could determine not just that planets exist, but also their actual masses and the tilts of their orbits—information that's usually much harder to pin down.

**Key Findings**

The team discovered four new cold Jupiters—massive planets with orbital periods ranging from about 1.2 to 28 years (compared to Jupiter's 12-year orbit around our Sun). The most massive weighs about five times more than Jupiter, while the smallest is roughly one-third Jupiter's mass. One particularly exciting find is a "Jupiter analog"—a planet with the longest known orbital period among planets in its mass range, taking over 28 years to complete one orbit. The researchers also found evidence that some planets in multi-planet systems may have tilted orbits relative to each other, suggesting complex gravitational interactions shaped these systems over time.

**Looking Forward**

This research demonstrates that combining multiple detection methods dramatically improves our ability to characterize distant worlds. The discovery of these cold Jupiters suggests many more are waiting to be found, potentially doubling or tripling the known population as future space missions collect more data. One of the newly discovered planets may even be bright enough for next-generation telescopes to photograph directly—a major step toward studying exoplanet atmospheres. These findings bring us closer to answering fundamental questions about planetary system formation and whether the architecture of our solar system is typical or unique in the cosmos.

papers.title: Aligned, Misaligned and Polar Orbits of Hot Jupiters: Measuring Spin-Orbit Angles via Doppler Tomography with HARPS-N
papers.abstract: Although the migration of hot Jupiters is not yet fully understood, measurements of the projected spin-orbit angle λ help shed light on the processes involved. Here we present Doppler tomography of three known hot Jupiters to determine their λ orientation: HAT-P-49 b, HAT-P-57A b, and XO-3A b. Our analysis explores the impact of cross-correlation processing methods on the detectability and characterization of the planet's Doppler shadow using up to three independent routines for cross-correlation functions extraction; those being: Yabi, iSpec and IRAF. After accounting for differences among the results obtained with the various routines, we report: first, the HAT-P-49 system is a case of a hot Jupiter on a polar orbit with λ=-85.3{\pm}1.7°, second, HAT-P-57A indicates practically no deviation of the planet's projected orbit from the host's equatorial plane with λ=-0.4^{+1.4}_{-1.9}°, and third, the XO-3A system with the measured value of λ=38{+3}_{-4}° lies in between an aligned and a perpendicular orientation, which is a less populated region of the spin-orbit distribution. Our findings highlight both the diversity of spin-orbit angles among close-in giant planets and the potential discrepancies in their measurement that can arise from different approaches to constructing the cross-correlation functions.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine if Earth orbited the Sun backwards, or if our planet looped around our star's poles instead of its equator. While that sounds like science fiction, astronomers are discovering that such bizarre arrangements are surprisingly common among planets orbiting other stars. These discoveries are revolutionizing our understanding of how planetary systems form and evolve, and they're making us reconsider just how special—or typical—our own solar system might be. By studying these cosmic oddballs, scientists can piece together the violent histories that shaped planetary systems across the galaxy, helping us understand whether Earth-like worlds and the conditions for life are rare cosmic accidents or natural outcomes of planet formation.

**What They Did**

The researchers used a sophisticated technique called Doppler tomography to study three "hot Jupiters"—massive planets similar to Jupiter but orbiting extremely close to their stars, completing full orbits in just days rather than years. Think of it like using a cosmic stethoscope: when these planets pass in front of their stars, they block specific colors of starlight in a way that reveals which direction they're traveling. By carefully analyzing this "shadow" in the starlight using three different computer programs, the team could determine whether each planet orbits in the same direction as its star spins (like planets in our solar system) or in some other, more chaotic arrangement. They used data from HARPS-N, a highly sensitive instrument designed to detect the tiniest changes in starlight.

**Key Findings**

The three planets revealed dramatically different stories. HAT-P-49 b shocked researchers by orbiting almost perfectly over its star's poles—imagine a planet traveling from the Sun's north pole to south pole instead of around its equator. HAT-P-57A b behaved more like planets in our solar system, orbiting neatly aligned with its star's rotation. XO-3A b fell somewhere in between, tilted at a 38-degree angle that represents a less common but intriguing middle ground. These measurements were remarkably precise, with uncertainties of just a few degrees.

**Looking Forward**

These findings highlight how diverse planetary systems can be, suggesting that the calm, orderly arrangement of our solar system may be more of an exception than the rule. The research also revealed that different analysis methods can produce varying results, pointing to the need for more standardized approaches in exoplanet research. As astronomers discover more of these tilted worlds, they're building a clearer picture of the chaotic processes that can reshape entire planetary systems—knowledge that will prove crucial as we search for potentially habitable worlds and try to understand how common Earth-like conditions might be throughout the universe.

papers.title: Metal Pipe: A Broadly-Applicable Stellar Abundance Pipeline Using Isochronal Parameters
papers.abstract: Characterizing exoplanet host stars at a population level requires a method of homogeneously characterizing stellar properties across all spectral types. To this end, we have developed Metal Pipe, a new code for determining stellar parameters and abundances, which is designed for use across a wider range of spectral types than many commonly used codes. It combines the widely-used package MOOG with photometric stellar parameters, a user-supplied high-resolution spectrum, and a newly curated list of spectral lines. Metal Pipe outputs values for $T_{\rm{eff}}$, $\log{(g)}$, $M_*$, $R_*$, and $L_*$ from isochrones, and abundances of C, O, Na, Mg, Al, Si, S, Ca, Ti, and Fe from MOOG. In this paper, we describe the Metal Pipe algorithm and tests of Metal Pipe against previous abundance measurements on archival HIRES spectra of 503 F, G, and K type stars. We find RMS scatters of ~100 K in $T_{\rm{eff}}$, ~0.10 dex in $\log{(g)}$, and ~0.10 dex for all measured abundances. These values are comparable to estimated measurement uncertainties, verifying Metal Pipe for continued use in building a detailed abundance catalog. Future papers in this series will test Metal Pipe's applicability to late K and M dwarf stars, and provide other improvements.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

The hunt for planets beyond our solar system has revealed thousands of alien worlds, but finding them is only half the battle. To truly understand these exoplanets—including which ones might harbor life—scientists need to know what their host stars are made of. Just as a plant's health depends on the soil it grows in, a planet's characteristics are intimately linked to the chemical makeup of the star it orbits around. Stars rich in heavy elements like iron and silicon tend to host rocky planets like Earth, while stars with different chemical recipes may produce entirely different types of worlds. But analyzing the chemical fingerprints of stars is like trying to determine the ingredients in thousands of different soup recipes by taste-testing them one by one—it requires consistent, reliable methods that work across many different types of stars.

**What They Did**

Researchers developed a new software tool called "Metal Pipe" (where "metals" in astronomy refers to any element heavier than hydrogen and helium) that acts like a universal translator for stellar chemistry. Think of it as creating a standardized recipe analyzer that can work on everything from chicken soup to beef stew. The tool combines two types of stellar data: light captured by telescopes that reveals the star's chemical signature, and brightness measurements that help determine the star's basic properties like temperature and size. They tested this new tool on 503 sun-like stars of different types, comparing their results to previous measurements to ensure accuracy.

**Key Findings**

The new tool proved remarkably precise, with measurements accurate to within about 100 degrees Kelvin in temperature (roughly the difference between a hot summer day and a mild spring day, but applied to stars burning at thousands of degrees). It can reliably detect ten different chemical elements in starlight and determine fundamental stellar properties with uncertainties of only about 10%—imagine measuring the height of a skyscraper and being off by just one floor.

**Looking Forward**

This breakthrough means astronomers can now efficiently analyze the chemical composition of thousands of exoplanet host stars using a single, consistent method. This will help reveal patterns between stellar chemistry and the types of planets that form, potentially guiding our search for Earth-like worlds and advancing our understanding of how planetary systems—including our own—came to be.

papers.title: KMT-2025-BLG-1616Lb: First Microlensing Bound Planet From DREAMS
papers.abstract: We present observations and analysis of the bound planetary microlensing event KMT-2025-BLG-1616. The planetary signal was captured by the Korea Microlensing Telescope Network (KMTNet) and the DECam Rogue Earths and Mars Survey (DREAMS). DREAMS's minute-cadence observations break the central/resonant degeneracy in the binary-lens models. The color of the faint source star ($I=22$) is measured from the DREAMS's $r - z$ color. The planetary system has a planet-host mass ratio of $q \sim 5 \times 10^{-4}$. A Bayesian analysis yields a host-star mass of $\sim 0.3\,M_\odot$, a planetary mass of $\sim 40\,M_{\oplus}$, a projected planet-host separation of $\sim 1.6~\mathrm{au}$, and a lens distance of $\sim 7.5~\mathrm{kpc}$. Based on the photometric precision achieved by DREAMS for this event, we simulate free-floating planet (FFP) detections and find that DREAMS is sensitive to Mars-mass FFPs in the Galactic bulge and Moon-mass FFPs in the Galactic disk.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**
This discovery marks the first planetary detection by DREAMS, a cutting-edge survey designed to find "rogue" planets that drift through space without orbiting stars. The research demonstrates a powerful new method for discovering distant planets and shows that astronomers can now detect planets as small as Mars floating freely in our galaxy, opening up an entirely new frontier in planet hunting.

**What They Did**
Astronomers used a technique called gravitational microlensing, where a planet and its host star act like a cosmic magnifying glass, briefly brightening the light from a more distant star as they pass in front of it. The DREAMS survey, using rapid-fire observations taken every minute, worked alongside the Korean telescope network to capture this fleeting planetary signal and measure the color of the distant background star.

**Key Findings**
The team discovered a Neptune-sized planet about 40 times more massive than Earth, orbiting a small red dwarf star roughly one-third the mass of our Sun. This planetary system lies approximately 7,500 parsecs (24,500 light-years) away in the direction of our galaxy's central bulge. The planet orbits at about 1.6 astronomical units from its host star—similar to the distance between our Sun and Mars. Most remarkably, the survey's precision suggests it could detect free-floating planets as small as Mars in the galaxy's central region and even Moon-sized rogues in the galactic disk.

**Looking Forward**
This success proves that DREAMS can achieve its ambitious goal of finding small rogue planets drifting through interstellar space, potentially revolutionizing our understanding of planetary formation and migration. The ability to detect such tiny, distant objects suggests that future surveys might uncover a vast population of free-floating worlds, reshaping our picture of how common planets really are in the universe.

papers.title: The impact of disc photoevaporation on the long-term evolution of giant planets in mean motion resonances
papers.abstract: We investigate the long-term impact of disc photoevaporation on the dynamical stability and evolution of giant planet pairs in mean motion resonances. Using two-dimensional hydrodynamical simulations with FARGO3D, in which we have included mass-loss due to photoevaporation, we explore a parameter space covering disc mass, viscosity, planet mass, and resonance type. We find that strong photoevaporation depletes gas in the common gap between the planets, slowing migration and suppressing planet-disc interactions that typically lead to resonance breaking and eccentricity damping. This stabilising effect is most significant for 3:2 resonances, which are more prone to disruption due to the reduced planet spacing. In contrast, 2:1 resonances are generally more robust but can still be destabilised at high disc mass and moderate-to-strong photoevaporation due to asymmetric torques. Photoevaporation can therefore stabilise resonances that would otherwise break, or conversely disrupt resonances that are natively more stable. Even in cases where photoevaporation does not directly affect resonance stability, it typically results in increased planetary eccentricities. These results highlight the complex, system-dependent nature of resonance evolution, with implications for the final orbital architectures of giant planet systems and their detectability via astrometry from missions such as Gaia.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**
Giant planets like Jupiter and Saturn often form in synchronized orbital patterns called resonances, where their orbital periods have simple mathematical relationships. Understanding how these delicate gravitational dances survive or break apart helps explain why our solar system looks different from many others discovered around distant stars, and affects our ability to detect these worlds using space telescopes.

**What They Did**
Scientists ran detailed computer simulations of planetary systems using a program called FARGO3D, modeling how pairs of giant planets behave when their birth discs of gas and dust get stripped away by radiation from their host star. They tested different combinations of disc properties, planet sizes, and resonance types (like 2:1 and 3:2 orbital ratios) to see what happens as the gas disappears through a process called photoevaporation.

**Key Findings**
The team discovered that photoevaporation creates surprising and contradictory effects depending on the specific system. When radiation strips away gas between two planets, it can actually stabilize some resonances by reducing disruptive interactions that would normally break them apart. However, the same process can destabilize other resonances by creating uneven gravitational forces. Systems in 3:2 resonances (where one planet completes three orbits for every two of its companion) proved more vulnerable to disruption, while 2:1 resonances showed greater resilience. Even when resonances survived, planets typically ended up on more stretched, oval-shaped orbits.

**Looking Forward**
These findings reveal that predicting planetary system evolution is far more complex than previously thought, with outcomes highly dependent on individual system characteristics. This complexity has important implications for space missions like Gaia, which seeks to detect distant planets by measuring their gravitational effects on host stars—different orbital configurations affect detectability in different ways.

papers.title: Central flashes during stellar occultations. Effects of diffraction, interferences, and stellar diameter
papers.abstract: Central flashes occur during stellar occultations by solar system objects. We catalog diffraction effects on the flash with point-like stars, monochromatic waves and spherical transparent atmosphere. Diffraction involves the Huygens principle, the Sommerfeld lemma and the stationary phase method, while finite stellar diameter cases involve Clausius' theorem. For point-like stars, the central flash shape is that of the classical Poisson spot, but with larger height. For tenuous atmospheres that cannot focus the stellar rays at shadow center, the flash is amplified by the factor (R_0/r_0)^2 compared to the Poisson spot, where R0 and r0 are the object and the shadow radii, respectively. For denser atmospheres that can focus the rays at shadow center, the flash peaks at 2[(pi*R/lambda_F})^2]*phi0, where R is the central flash layer radius, lambda_F is the Fresnel scale and phi0 is the flux that would be observed at shadow center without focusing. For isothermal atmospheres with scale height H, the height is 2(R*H)(pi/lambda_F)^2. Fringes surrounding the central flash are separated by lambda_P=lambda_F^2/R, related to the separation between the primary and secondary stellar images. For a projected stellar diameter D*>lambda_P, the flash is described by complete elliptic integrals, and has full width at half maximum of 1.14D* and peak value 8H/D*. For Earth-based occultations by Pluto and Triton observed in the visible with point-like stars, diffraction causes flashes with very large heights ~10e4-10e5, spread over a very small meter-sized region in the shadow plane. In practice, the flash is usually smoothed by the stellar diameter, but still reaches high values of ~50 and ~200 during Pluto and Triton occultations, respectively. Diffraction dominates when using millimeter wavelengths or longer. Effects of departure from sphericity, atmospheric waves and stellar limb darkening are discussed.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**
When planets, moons, or asteroids pass in front of distant stars (called stellar occultations), they create mysterious bright flashes of light at the center of their shadows—a phenomenon that has puzzled astronomers for decades. Understanding these "central flashes" is crucial for accurately measuring the atmospheres and sizes of distant worlds in our solar system, turning these cosmic alignments into powerful scientific tools.

**What They Did**
The researchers developed detailed mathematical models to explain how light behaves when it passes through the thin atmospheres of distant objects during occultations. They used principles of wave physics—specifically how light waves bend, interfere, and focus—to predict the brightness and shape of central flashes under different atmospheric conditions. Their calculations considered everything from point-like stars to stars with measurable diameters, and from very thin to moderately dense atmospheres.

**Key Findings**
The team discovered that central flashes are essentially supercharged versions of the famous "Poisson spot"—a bright point that appears in shadows due to light waves bending around circular objects. For thin atmospheres like those around Pluto and Neptune's moon Triton, these flashes can be incredibly intense—thousands to hundreds of thousands of times brighter than normal—but concentrated in areas just meters wide. The exact brightness and shape depend on the atmosphere's density and the size of the occulting object. When observed from Earth with visible light, these flashes are often smoothed out by the star's own diameter, but still produce dramatic brightening of 50 times normal for Pluto and 200 times for Triton.

**Looking Forward**
These findings will help astronomers better interpret occultation observations, leading to more precise measurements of atmospheric properties on distant worlds. The research is particularly relevant as new telescopes and techniques allow scientists to study smaller and more distant objects, where these diffraction effects become increasingly important for extracting accurate scientific data.

Why It Matters

When planets, moons, or asteroids pass in front of distant stars (called stellar occultations), they create mysterious bright flashes of light at the center of their shadows—a phenomenon that has puzzled astronomers for decades. Understanding these "central flashes" is crucial for accurately measuring the atmospheres and sizes of distant worlds in our solar system, turning these cosmic alignments into powerful scientific tools.

What They Did

The researchers developed detailed mathematical models to explain how light behaves when it passes through the thin atmospheres of distant objects during occultations. They used principles of wave physics—specifically how light waves bend, interfere, and focus—to predict the brightness and shape of central flashes under different atmospheric conditions. Their calculations considered everything from point-like stars to stars with measurable diameters, and from very thin to moderately dense atmospheres.

Key Findings

The team discovered that central flashes are essentially supercharged versions of the famous "Poisson spot"—a bright point that appears in shadows due to light waves bending around circular objects. For thin atmospheres like those around Pluto and Neptune's moon Triton, these flashes can be incredibly intense—thousands to hundreds of thousands of times brighter than normal—but concentrated in areas just meters wide. The exact brightness and shape depend on the atmosphere's density and the size of the occulting object. When observed from Earth with visible light, these flashes are often smoothed out by the star's own diameter, but still produce dramatic brightening of 50 times normal for Pluto and 200 times for Triton.

Looking Forward

These findings will help astronomers better interpret occultation observations, leading to more precise measurements of atmospheric properties on distant worlds. The research is particularly relevant as new telescopes and techniques allow scientists to study smaller and more distant objects, where these diffraction effects become increasingly important for extracting accurate scientific data.

tweet_hook.hook: Stellar occultations create central flashes thousands of times brighter than expected
tweet_hook.claim: New diffraction analysis reveals occultation flashes can reach amplifications of 10⁴-10⁵ for point sources
tweet_hook.evidence: Pluto and Triton occultations still show 50x and 200x brightness peaks despite stellar smoothing
tweet_hook.question: Could this explain unexpected brightness variations in your occultation observations?

papers.title: Rotation Period of 3I/ATLAS After Perihelion from Jet Position Angle Wobble and Photometric Variability
papers.abstract: We determine the post-perihelion rotation period of 3I/ATLAS using two independent diagnostics: the temporal modulation of the position angle (PA) of a persistent jet-like feature, and a time-series photometric light curve in the Gr (R) band. For the jet morphology, we measure the PA at multiple epochs by applying the Larson-Sekanina Rotational Gradient filter to Hubble Space Telescope images between November 20, 2025 and December 27, 2025, and model the phase-folded PA curve with weighted least-squares Fourier series up to two harmonics while scanning trial periods P to identify minima in \c{hi}2(P). For the photometry, we adopt the best-fit period from an independent 30-minute binned analysis (from a 0.25 meter telescope MPC L92) based on a refined \c{hi}2(P) profile for a sinusoidal model with nightly offsets. We find that the jet-PA modulation gives a period Pjet = 7.20 +/-0.05 h (adopting a conservative uncertainty dominated by sparse sampling and systematics), while the photometry yields Pphot = 7.136+/-0.001 h (formal 1σ uncertainty). Although the periods differ slightly, the offset is plausibly attributable to non-Gaussian systematics and aliasing. The combined data supports a post-perihelion rotation period of 7.1 h associated with precession of the jet structure around the rotation axis by 20°. The rotation axis is aligned with the sunward direction to within 20°
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**
Scientists have successfully measured how fast an interstellar comet spins by watching its jets wobble and tracking its brightness changes. This is only the second known visitor from another star system, making it a rare opportunity to study material from beyond our solar system and understand how comets behave when they travel between stars.

**What They Did**
Researchers used the Hubble Space Telescope to photograph comet 3I/ATLAS multiple times over more than a month, carefully measuring how a prominent jet of gas and dust changed direction as the comet rotated. They also monitored how the comet's brightness varied over time using a ground-based telescope, since spinning comets typically get brighter and dimmer as different surfaces face Earth.

**Key Findings**
The team discovered that this interstellar visitor completes one full rotation every 7.1 hours, spinning relatively quickly compared to many comets in our solar system. The persistent jet doesn't point straight out from the comet's rotation axis but instead wobbles around it by about 20 degrees, creating a cone-like pattern as the comet spins. Both the jet's wobbling motion and the brightness variations gave nearly identical rotation periods, confirming their measurement. The comet's rotation axis points almost directly toward the Sun, which is an unusual but not unprecedented orientation.

**Looking Forward**
Understanding how this interstellar comet rotates helps scientists learn about the forces that shaped it during its long journey through space and how it responds to heating from our Sun. These measurements will improve models of how interstellar objects behave and help astronomers better study future visitors from other star systems, which are expected to be discovered more frequently as telescope technology advances.
